title: RL33669
content: The National Security Agency (NSA) faced scrutiny over the secret Terrorist Surveillance Program (TSP), sparking a national debate on its legality under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) and the need for additional authority. The program involved warrantless surveillance of international communications involving individuals believed to be associated with al Qaeda. Congress should oversee the TSP program involving surveillance without a warrant under FISA of international communications of persons within the US believed to be linked to al Qaeda. The Bush Administration claimed constitutional and statutory support for the program. Senator Mitch McConnell introduced the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006. The Bush Administration supported the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 introduced by Senator Mitch McConnell in Congress to address electronic surveillance programs for acquiring foreign intelligence related to al Qaeda. The Terrorist Tracking, Identification and Prosecution Act of 2006, including the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006, was introduced in Congress to address electronic surveillance programs for detecting and preventing international terrorist threats. Related bills have been introduced in subsequent Congresses. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, enacted in 1978, provides a framework for electronic surveillance to acquire foreign intelligence information. Three bills introduced in the 110th Congress aim to assist in detecting and preventing international terrorist threats to the United States. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) provides a statutory framework for electronic surveillance to acquire foreign intelligence information. The Bush Administration argued that FISA lacked the speed and agility to combat terrorism effectively. The Bush Administration argued that FISA lacked speed and agility in combating terrorism, leading to the authorization of electronic surveillance by a FISC judge for international communications related to terrorism. Attorney General Gonzales informed the Senate Judiciary Committee that FISC judges had authorized the government to target international communications involving suspected terrorists. This new approval process replaces the previous surveillance program for increased oversight. The Attorney General announced that surveillance previously conducted under the TSP will now be subject to FISC approval, with the President deciding not to reauthorize the program when the current authorization expires. Intelligence Committees were briefed on the classified FISC orders. The President has decided not to reauthorize the TSP when the current authorization expires. The Attorney General has directed a classified briefing on FISC orders for Intelligence Committees. The NSA program faces legal challenges. The President has decided not to reauthorize the TSP when the current authorization expires. The Attorney General has directed a classified briefing on FISC orders for Intelligence Committees. The NSA program faces legal challenges, with a lawsuit ruling it unconstitutional on various grounds. In a case against the National Security Agency, Judge Anna Diggs Taylor ruled the program unconstitutional for violating various laws and the U.S. Constitution. The decision was appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, which stayed the judgment pending appeal. The National Security Agency's Terrorist Surveillance Program was ruled unconstitutional by Judge Anna Diggs Taylor for violating laws and the U.S. Constitution. The decision was appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, which stayed the judgment pending appeal. The appeal process included a letter from the appellants' attorneys regarding orders issued by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) and Title III of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act. The appeal in American Civil Liberties Union v. National Security Agency, Docket Nos. 06-2140 and 06-2095, involved a letter from the appellants' attorneys regarding orders from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. Proposed legislation, S. 3931 and Title II of S. 3929, aimed to address electronic surveillance programs under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. Proposed legislation S. 3931 and Title II of S. 3929 would create a new Title VII of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 to address electronic surveillance programs and amend other provisions of FISA related to electronic surveillance without a warrant. The proposed legislation S. 3931 and Title II of S. 3929 aim to address electronic surveillance programs under a new Title VII of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. This includes applications for Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court orders, emergency surveillance under FISA, limitations on liability for aiding electronic surveillance, and changes to FISA definitions. The bills would also repeal wartime authorities for surveillance without a warrant following a congressional declaration of war. The proposed legislation aims to address electronic surveillance programs under a new Title VII of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. It includes changes to FISA definitions, repealing wartime authorities for surveillance without a warrant, and modifying criminal provisions related to electronic surveillance. The Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 proposes changes to FISA, including the creation of a new Title VII for electronic surveillance programs. This new section defines "electronic surveillance program" and addresses the international movements of surveillance targets. The Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 introduces changes to FISA, including the creation of a new Title VII for electronic surveillance programs. This new section defines "electronic surveillance program" and addresses the international movements of surveillance targets under FISA. The new Section 701 of FISA defines an electronic surveillance program as one with the significant purpose of gathering foreign intelligence information or protecting against international terrorism. It allows for surveillance without naming specific targets and immediate action upon suspect activity. The new Section 702(a) of FISA allows for electronic surveillance programs to gather foreign intelligence information or protect against international terrorism. The FISC reviews, authorizes, and reauthorizes these programs, with initial authorization lasting up to 90 days and reauthorization for longer periods. The new Section 702(a) of FISA grants jurisdiction to the FISC to review, authorize, and reauthorize electronic surveillance programs for obtaining foreign intelligence or combating international terrorism. Initial authorization can last up to 90 days, with reauthorization for a reasonable period determined by the FISC. If an application is denied, the Attorney General can submit new applications or appeal the decision to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The FISC can authorize and reauthorize electronic surveillance programs under Section 702(a) of FISA for up to 90 days initially, with reauthorization for a reasonable period. If an application is denied, the Attorney General can submit new applications or appeal to the FIS Court of Review. The Attorney General can appeal FISC decisions to the FIS Court of Review regarding surveillance under Title VII of FISA. If criteria for electronic surveillance are met, surveillance must be discontinued unless certain conditions are fulfilled. Surveillance can only continue under Title VII if deemed practicable by the Attorney General. The Attorney General must discontinue surveillance under Title VII of FISA unless specific conditions are met. If deemed practicable, the Attorney General can continue surveillance under Title VII by applying for an FISC order under Section 104 of FISA. The Attorney General can continue surveillance under Title VII by applying for a FISC order under Section 104 of FISA, as per new Section 702(a)(4) of FISA and related bills. Congressional oversight includes AG reports every 180 days to intelligence committees. Sec. 8 of S. 3931 and Sec. 208 of S. 3929 require AG reports every 180 days to congressional intelligence committees on electronic surveillance activities authorized under FISA. Amendments are made to FISA to ensure oversight by Congress. Sec. 8 of S. 3931 and Sec. 208 of S. 3929 amend FISA by repealing sections that allow the President to authorize surveillance without a court order for up to 15 days following a declaration of emergency. The President's authority to authorize surveillance without a court order under FISA is being repealed by S. 3929. This includes electronic surveillance, physical searches, and the use of pen register or trap and trace devices for up to 15 days after a declaration of war by Congress. 18 U.S.C. § 2511 prohibits interception of communications, with specific exceptions outlined in the current law. Current 18 U.S.C. § 2511 prohibits interception of communications, with specific exceptions outlined in the law, including authorization for electronic surveillance by U.S. officers in the course of official duties following a declaration of war. The amended subsection 2511(2)(e) allows U.S. officers to conduct electronic surveillance in the normal course of official duty under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The amended subsection 2511(2)(e) allows U.S. officers to conduct electronic surveillance in the normal course of official duty under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, as authorized by that Act. Current 18 U.S.C. § 2511(2)(f) states that nothing in the chapter shall affect the acquisition of foreign intelligence information by the U.S. Government from international or foreign communications, conducted in accordance with applicable Federal law using means other than electronic surveillance as defined in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The exclusive means for conducting electronic surveillance and intercepting domestic communications is outlined in 18 U.S.C. § 2511(2)(f), allowing the U.S. Government to acquire foreign intelligence information through non-electronic surveillance methods in accordance with applicable Federal law. The exclusive means for conducting electronic surveillance and intercepting domestic communications is outlined in 18 U.S.C. § 2511(2)(f), allowing the U.S. Government to acquire foreign intelligence information through non-electronic surveillance methods in accordance with applicable Federal law. This provision prohibits electronic surveillance unless conducted under the provisions of FISA, chapter 119, or chapter 121 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The amendment to 18 U.S.C. § 2511(2)(f) clarifies that the U.S. Government can acquire foreign intelligence information authorized by Federal law or the Constitution. The amendments in S. 3931 and S. 3929 address criminal liability for unauthorized electronic surveillance under the Federal statute or the Constitution of the United States, including engaging in electronic surveillance not authorized by law and disclosing or using information obtained through unauthorized surveillance. The proposed amendments in S. 3931 and S. 3929 aim to increase penalties for unauthorized electronic surveillance, including engaging in surveillance not authorized by law and disclosing information obtained through unauthorized surveillance. Penalties would be raised from a fine of up to $10,000 to a fine of up to $100,000. Under the proposed amendments in S. 3931 and S. 3929, penalties for unauthorized electronic surveillance would be increased significantly. Under the new definition, "electronic surveillance" would mean the intentional surveillance of a known person using surveillance devices. Minimization procedures aim to limit acquisition and dissemination of non-public information of unconsenting US persons during foreign intelligence activities. The procedures under FISA aim to limit acquisition and dissemination of non-public information of unconsenting US persons during foreign intelligence activities, while allowing retention and dissemination of evidence of criminal activity to law enforcement. Non-publicly available information not related to foreign intelligence shall not be disseminated in a way that identifies any US person without consent, unless necessary for understanding foreign intelligence. The procedures under FISA allow for retention and dissemination of evidence of criminal activity to law enforcement.
